Award.AwardTitle: Student Support: 52nd Annual Technical Meeting of the Society of Engineering Science (SES); College Station, Texas

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support student activities within the 52nd Annual Technical Meeting of the Society of Engineering Science (SES), to be held October 26 - 28, 2015 on the campus of Texas A&M University - College Station. The SES technical meeting is held annually and provides a forum for the discussion and dissemination of recent advances in research and education in topics from all areas of engineering science. The meeting emphasizes topics on the science and mechanics of solid and fluid media in a setting that is mostly devoted to fundamental research and education. The organizers anticipate participation of researchers presenting more than 500 papers, organized in 32 symposia. Each symposium is organized by leaders in their respective fields and consists primarily of invited participants.

The SES meeting builds on a tradition of emphasis on interdisciplinary research at the boundaries of science and engineering. This award will facilitate the participation of students competing in a poster competition. Through this award, a diverse group of graduate students will have the opportunity to present their research and interact with their peers and with recognized authorities in their field of choice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes Report

 

The goal of this project was to support 30 students to attend the 52nd Annual Technical Meeting of the Society of Engineering Science (SES) held on October 26-28, 2015 at Texas A&M University in College Station, TX, and participate in the associated Student Poster Competition. There are currently 12 SES student chapters: Arizona State University, Georgia Institute of Technology, Iowa State University, Michigan State University, Northwestern University, Texas A&M University, Pennsylvania State University, University of California-Berkeley, University of Florida, University of Tennessee, University of Utah, and Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University. Each of the chapters were contacted about the poster competition and information about the poster student poster competition was added to the SES 2015 website. NSF funding was in the form of waived registration and travel reimbursements to the funded students.

 

Intellectual Merit: The student posters were on display throughout the conference in the break room to promote interaction between the poster presenters and other participants, as well as disseminate the student research. In addition, a reception was held in the poster area on Tuesday evening. The top three posters presentations (abstract, poster, student discussion), as determined by a team of judges, were awarded a cash prize.

 

Broader Impacts: The NSF funds provided opportunity for the students to attend and participate in the SES annual meeting, possibly their first (and perhaps only) such opportunity. All of the student participants had the valuable professional experience of preparing their poster and interacting with others in their field, including experts and seasoned researchers. There were 85 finalists in the Student Poster Competition, 53 of these students from 26 different universities received funding through this grant, including 5 of the SES student chapters (Iowa State, Arizona State, TAMU, GA Tech, and VA Tech). Overall student attendance was nearly 1/3 of the meeting’s attendance at 102 of the 322 in attendance.

 


Last Modified: 01/05/2017
Modified by: Dimitris C Lagoudas
